thread.title: Healthier food, larger and pricier beers among Target Field's new options
thread.title_full: Healthier food, larger and pricier beers among Target Field's new options - StarTribune.com

author: Paul Walsh
title: Healthier food, larger and pricier beers among Target Field's new options
text:
Just as the Twins revamp their lineup every season — especially after one as distasteful as 2016 — the food roster at Target Field is also getting a makeover, with new dishes that creators hope are a hit with fans starting with Opening Day on Monday.
And in an effort to touch all the bases, several healthier options are being added.
As far as liquid refreshments, Twins fans will be paying heftier prices for beer, although some of that can be attributed to bumping up some of the offerings from 12 to 16 ounces.
Domestic draft beers are heading north by 50 cents and now range from $8 to $10.50. Examples of others growing in price but also size: 16-ounce Shell’s, Summit and Bauhaus rising $2 to $9.50.
From northeast Minneapolis comes the Herbivorous Butcher’s popular vegan specialties, a meat-free Sriracha brat and vegan Italian sausage (both $12.50). They can be found paired with the MSP Kosher Hot Dog cart at section 129.
Minnesota’s own global gastronomic giant Andrew Zimmern is growing his Canteen-Skewers venue and introducing new Mediterranean-style skewer flatbread sandwiches at section 114. Patrons choose their favorite meat, and each sandwich is served with roasted eggplant spread, herbed yogurt sauce, and tomato and cucumber. Kyndell Harkness Gallery: New food at Target Field 
Now, for some guilty indulgences, here are additions to the lineup for 2017.
From nearby Loring Park, the popular 4 Bells restaurant will bring to the stadium its signature shrimp boil featuring shrimp, corn, potatoes and sausage ($14.50).
A longtime downtown Minneapolis institution, Murray’s, is expanding its Target Field presence with a new cart in section 116 serving fresh-shaved smoked beef sandwiches on a roll toasted with its famous garlic butter and a side of house-cut seasoned chips ($14.50).
The Cookie Cart, an urban nonprofit bakery run by teens, debuts at section 101 during Saturday and Sunday games all season long.
To save folk the trouble of trekking along the concourse looking for a favorite from last season, these dishes have been given the heave-ho: Rib Tips from Butcher and the Boar, Murray’s steak and Philly sandwich, pork chop on a stick, and fried pickles.
For a full rundown of concessions — and their prices — go to atmlb.com/1sr33ni.
